member.name: T:Sdgt.Keyboard
member.summary: A Single Display Groupware Keyboard

remarks.para: This class provides little functionality other than a set of events specific to this keyboard and storage of all the individual key states.

member.name: M:Sdgt.Keyboard.#ctor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The Default Keyboard Constructor

member.name: P:Sdgt.Keyboard.Mouse
member.summary: Gets or sets the current mouse whose focus all keyboard events will be mapped to

remarks.para: Single Display Groupare often breaks many rules in traditional single user applications. The problem is in single display groupware you may have a one mouse and two keyboard situation. In this case it may be apropriate to map two keyboards to one mouse focus. This utility allows the programmer to map the various keyboards on the system to whichever mouse they desire.

member.name: E:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyDown
member.summary: Event fired when a key is pressed

member.name: E:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyUp
member.summary: Event fired when a key is released

member.name: E:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyPress
member.summary: Event fired when a key is pressed

member.name: T:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyboardCollection
member.summary: A class which inherits from ReadOnlyCollection Base and represents a collection of keyboards

remarks.para: To access different keyboards on the system a collection class was needed. This class will provide array access to the class and will provide a count of the total number of keyboards on the system.

member.name: M:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyboardCollection.#ctor(System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: The default constructor for a keyboard collection. Requires an arraylist of keyboards

member.name: P:Sdgt.Keyboard.KeyboardCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the keyboard class specified by the index parameter

remarks.para: There are several ways to iterate through all of the keyboards on the system. One can use a numeric iterator such as "int i" or use a mouse iterator using the foreach parameter.

example.para: C# Eg., for (int i=0; i < sdgManager1.Keyboards.Count; ++i) { }
C# Eg., foreach (Sdgt.Keyboard k in sdgManager1.Keyboards) { }

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventHandler
member.summary: Keyboard event handler for key up and key down events

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventHandler
member.summary: Keyboard event handler for key press events

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs
member.summary: Event Arguments for the default keyboard press event

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs.#ctor
member.summary: The Default Constructor for the key press event arguments

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs.KeyChar
member.summary: Gets the ASCII equivalent of the character just pressed

remarks.para: Some keys such as f1 do not have ascii equivalents. These keys will return null as the KeyChar value. The Ascii Character takes into account the use of the shift key and ignores the control and alt keys.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs.ID
member.summary: Gets the ID of the keyboard which raised this event

remarks.para: This is the only property that is added from the normal .NET keyboard event

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs.Handled
member.summary: Gets a boolean value describing if this event has been handled by another component

remarks.para: Sometimes a keyboard event could be handled by a text box or form. You are told wether or not this keyboard event has been handled by another control through the handled property.

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs
member.summary: Event Arguments for the default keyboard down and up events

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.#ctor
member.summary: The Default Constructor for the key up and down event arguments

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.Alt
member.summary: Gets a boolean value representing the current state of the Alt key

remarks.para: This is a simple utility to determine if the either or both of the Alt keys are pressed down.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.Control
member.summary: Gets a boolean value representing the current state of the Control key

remarks.para: This is a simple utility to determine if the either or both of the Control keys are pressed down.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.Handled
member.summary: Gets a boolean value describing if this event has been handled by another component

remarks.para: Sometimes a keyboard event could be handled by a text box or form. You are told wether or not this keyboard event has been handled by another control through the handled property.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.Shift
member.summary: Gets a boolean value representing the current state of the Shift key

remarks.para: This is a simple utility to determine if the either or both of the Shift keys are pressed down. The caps lock key is also taken into consideration for this value

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.ID
member.summary: Gets the ID of the keyboard which raised this event

remarks.para: This is the only property that is added from the normal .NET keyboard event

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.KeyCode
member.summary: Gets the Keys enumeration of the current key pressed without modifiers such as Alt, Control and Shift

remarks.para: If you would like to know which key is currently being pressed this property provides this functionality

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.KeyData
member.summary: Gets the Keys enumeration of the current key pressed with modifiers such as Alt, Control and Shift

remarks.para: This functin provides you with a list of all the keys currently pressed.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.KeyValue
member.summary: Gets a numeric value representing the acsii character of the key pressed

remarks.para: This is a quick and easy method of determining the Ascii character that would have been produced if this key was typed in a text box.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs.Modifiers
member.summary: Returns a Keys enumeration of all the modifiers used (such as Alt, Control and Shift) in the key event

remarks.para: This is useful for telling you which of Control, Alt and Shift are current depressed

member.name: T:Sdgt.EmulateSystemMouseModes
member.summary: The different types of System Mouse Emulation Modes

remarks.para: There may be cases where you actually want the system mouse to follow a particular mouse or you may want to park the system mouse in a particular location so to prevent problems which clicking in a location outside the mouse area. This enumeration provides that functionality.

member.name: F:Sdgt.EmulateSystemMouseModes.Park
member.summary: Park the system mouse at the location specified by SystemMouseParkLocation

member.name: F:Sdgt.EmulateSystemMouseModes.FollowMouse
member.summary: Follow the mouse specified by the MouseToFollow property

member.name: T:Sdgt.ScaleModes
member.summary: The different types of coordinates provided in each mouse event

remarks.para: A programmer may be interested in delta values rather than mouse coordinates. This enumeration describes the different coordinate systems offered.

member.name: F:Sdgt.ScaleModes.Pixel
member.summary: All coordinates are absolute, and can be made relative to a form through the RelativeTo property

member.name: F:Sdgt.ScaleModes.PixelDelta
member.summary: All coordinates are relative to the last set of coordinates. The programmer works with delta values

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgManager
member.summary: This is the manager for all input events and also sends events to all sdg aware widgets

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.#ctor
member.summary: SDG Manager Constructor: Must be added to a container before the Toolkit becomes active.

remarks.para: This constructor does not actually start the sdg manager until it is added to a container.

example.para: C# e.g., sdgManager1 = new sdgManager(); this.components.Add(sdgManager1);
The above code assumes that this.components is not null.

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.#ctor(System.ComponentModel.IContainer)
member.summary: The default constructor automatically called when the component is dragged onto the form

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.Finalize
member.summary: Default destructor for the sdgManager class

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.Dispose
member.summary: Function used to delete the current SDG Manager and restore the computer back to it's previous state

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.AttachEventSinkWidget(Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget,System.Windows.Forms.Control)
member.summary: Adds a widget that will recieve all SDG Mouse and Keyboard events (e.g., the SDG Form)
member.param: The widget that will recieve SDG Mouse and Keyboard events
The control that coorindates should be relative to

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.AttachEventSinkWidget(Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget)
member.summary: Adds a widget that will recieve all SDG Mouse and Keyboard events (e.g., the SDG Form)
member.param: The widget that will recieve SDG Mouse and Keyboard events

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgManager.InitializeComponent
member.summary: Required method for Designer support - do not modify the contents of this method with the code editor.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.Site
member.summary: Gets or sets the Site interface associated with this component. The SDG Manager starts only after it has been added to a container.

remarks.para: You need not set the ISite directly. The ISite is automatically set when the class is added to a container (e.g., this.components.Add(sdgManager1);)

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.Mice
member.summary: Gets or sets the mouse class specified by the index parameter

remarks.para: There are several ways to iterate through all of the mice on the system. One can use a numeric iterator such as "int i" or use a mouse iterator using the foreach parameter.

example.para: C# Eg., for (int i=0; i < sdgManager1.Mice.Count; ++i) { sdgManager1.Mice[i].Text = "Tricks are for kids"; }
C# Eg., foreach (Sdgt.Mouse m in sdgManager1.Mice) { m.Text = "Tricks are for kids"; }

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.Keyboards
member.summary: Gets or sets the keyboard class specified by the index parameter

remarks.para: There are several ways to iterate through all of the keyboards on the system. One can use a numeric iterator such as "int i" or use a mouse iterator using the foreach parameter.

example.para: C# Eg., for (int i=0; i < sdgManager1.Keyboards.Count; ++i) { }
C# Eg., foreach (Sdgt.Keyboard k in sdgManager1.Keyboards) { }

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.EmulateSystemMouseMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the System Mouse Emulation Mode

remarks.para: There may be cases where you actually want the system mouse to follow mouse 0 or you may want to park the system mouse in a particular location so to prevent problems which clicking in a location outside the mouse area. This enumeration provides that functionality.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseToFollow
member.summary: Gets or sets the mouse the system mouse will follow

remarks.para: There may be cases where you actually want the system mouse to follow a particular mouse to allow the normal interaction with Windows widgets. This property specifies which system mouse should be followed

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.ParkSystemMouseLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the location where the system mouse cursor will be parked

remarks.para: To prevent the system mouse from being seen in the application and to prevent mouse clicks from going astray and losing focus of the application it may be necessary to park the mosue in a particular location.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgManager.RelativeTo
member.summary: Gets or sets the Control class to which all mouse events will be relative to

remarks.para: This function makes all cursor coordinates relative to a particular part of the screen. This function allows a user to make their coordinates relative to a particular control.

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseMove
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse event occurs

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseDown
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse button has been pressed

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseUp
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse button has been released

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseWheel
member.summary: Event fired when the mouse wheel has been moved

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.MouseAttached
member.summary: Event fired when a new mouse has been detected

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.KeyDown
member.summary: Event fired when a key is pressed

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.KeyUp
member.summary: Event fired when a key is released

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.KeyPress
member.summary: Event fired when a key is pressed

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgManager.KeyAttatched
member.summary: Event fired when a new keyboard has been detected

member.name: T:Sdgt.CardinalDirections
member.summary: The cardinal directions enumeration is useful for rotating the cursor in specific directions. It assumes a default cursor rotation

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.Normal
member.summary: Normal

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.North
member.summary: North

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.NorthEast
member.summary: North East

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.East
member.summary: East

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.SouthEast
member.summary: South East

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.South
member.summary: South

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.SouthWest
member.summary: South West

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.West
member.summary: West

member.name: F:Sdgt.CardinalDirections.NorthWest
member.summary: North West

member.name: T:Sdgt.Mouse
member.summary: An sdg mouse class, this class handles all mouse movements and fires events specific to this mouse

remarks.para: An sdg mouse is a window which moves when it's X and Y values are changed. It handles cursor movement and rotation. It is possible to create a dummy sdg mouse which you can control manually by using the constructor that does require an IntPtr as the first variable

member.name: M:Sdgt.Mouse.#ctor(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: The Default Mouse Constructor. Requires a pointer to a mouse

member.name: M:Sdgt.Mouse.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Specialized Mouse Constructor used if you want to create a dummy mouse that just moves around the screen

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Hotspot
member.summary: Get or sets the Hotspot of the cursor. The hotspot is the focal area of a cursor

remarks.para: Changing the hotspot is usually the result of an error on my part. However, if you decide to create your own cursor and don't customize your own cursor this function may be of great use to you.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.RotateCursorImageOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation of the cursor image. This does not affect the movement of the cursor

remarks.para: There may be the case where you want to rotate just the cursor image without rotating the movement of the cursor. This utility provides that functionality. Please note that this can also be used with the CardinalDirections enumeraton.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.DegreeRotation
member.summary: Gets or sets both the rotation of the cursor image and the rotation of the movement of the cursor. For table top displays

remarks.para: Table Top applications often require the rotation of cursors and cursor movement. When one is rotated 180Â° from the upright screen position moving the mouse awat from the user will move the cursor towards the user instead of away from the user.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets the visible property of the Mouse. This is useful if you just want Mouse Events but you don't want to draw the Mouse on the screen

remarks.para: If a user adds mutliple sdgManagers to a form they may not want multiple cursors for each sdgManager. This utility provides the means to prevent the drawing of another cursor on the screen.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Cursor
member.summary: Gets or sets the cursor image. You can use one of the default System.Windows.Forms.Cursors

remarks.para: Often in an sdg application you may want to customize the cursor for different users of the application. The cursor property allows you to use the default windows cursors and your own custom .cur files. Please note that animated cursors and inverted colours are currently not supported.

There have been some issues noted with the loading of cursors that are not black and white and 32x32 pixels, unfortunately these problems are systemic in the .NET framework implementation of the cursor class. We expect this issue to be solved but in the mean time to create a cursor in Visual Studio .NET go File->New->File->Visual C++->Cursor File.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Xabs
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute X screen position of the current Mouse

remarks.para: Often it may be useful to obtain the absolute X position of the cursor without the need to worry about it being relative to the form. Xabs provides this functionality

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Yabs
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute Y screen position of the current Mouse

remarks.para: Often it may be useful to obtain the absolute Y position of the cursor without the need to worry about it being relative to the form. Yabs provides this functionality

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.LocationAbs
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute screen position of the current Mouse

remarks.para: Often it may be useful to obtain the absolute position of the cursor without the need to worry about it being relative to the form. LocationAbs provides this functionality

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.X
member.summary: Gets or sets the X position of the cursor relative to the specified control

remarks.para: X provides the same coordinates that are provided in the Mouse Event. You can move to mouse to a particular location by setting the mouse value.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Y
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y position of the cursor relative to the specified control

remarks.para: Y provides the same coordinates that are provided in the Mouse Event. You can move to mouse to a particular location by setting the mouse value.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the cursor relative to the specified control

remarks.para: Location provides the same coordinates that are provided in the Mouse Event. You can move to mouse to a particular location by setting the mouse value.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.RelativeTo
member.summary: Gets or sets the control that all of the X, Y and Location coordinates are relative to

remarks.para: This function makes all of the cursor coordinates relative to a particular part of the screen. This function allows a user to make their coordinates relative to a particular control.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the cursor caption. The Default text location is the bottom left of the screen

remarks.para: To customize a cursor (with a name or identifier) simply add text to the text property.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.TextFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the cursor caption string format. The default format is to draw all text in a left to right fashion moving right from TextLocation

remarks.para: It may be useful to orient the text with different alignments (left, center, right). The StringFormat class provides the ability to start and move in different directions. For more information see the StringFormat class.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.TextBrush
member.summary: Gets or sets the cursor caption brush. This is useful for changing the colour of the text

remarks.para: To change the colour of the text or change the way text is drawn on the screen one may want to set the cursor caption brush.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.TextLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the starting location of the text caption for this cursor.

remarks.para: This command allows the programmer to change the starting location of the text caption.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.TextFont
member.summary: Gets or sets the font of the text caption for this cursor.

remarks.para: This command allows the programmer to change the font type and size of the text caption.

example.para: C# Eg., sdgManager1.Mice[0].TextFont = new Font("Times New Roman", 12);

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.TextCardinalPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of the text caption based upon the Cardinal Direction enumeration. Normal returns a value dead center of the cursor.

remarks.para: To change the text cursor to various different locations relative to the cursor. If text is located on the northwest part of the cursor then a programmer will probably want the text right justified and relative to the top left corner. The Cardinal Position enumeration provides a base set of text locations. More custom positions can be produced using the TextFormat and TextLocation properties.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Opacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the opacity of the cursor. A value of 1.0 represents full opacity and 0.0 represents completely transparent

remarks.para: It may be useful to make a cursor more transparent to avoid occulsion effects from a cursor. Opacity changes the cursor transparency from fully opaque (1.0) to fully transparent (0.0). Please note that opacity has been known to dramatically decrease mouse performance on machines without hardware accelerated transparent windows.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Button
member.summary: Gets an enumeration of all the mouse buttons currently pressed down

remarks.para: The mouse class keeps track of which buttons are pressed down. Please note that it is possible for more than one mouse button to be pressed at any given time.

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.Focus
member.summary: Gets or sets the current SDG widget that this mouse is focused on

remarks.para: Each mouse has it's own focus. When a keyboard event occurs, the SDG manager recieves focus from the widget

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.ControlFocus
member.summary: Gets or sets the current Control that this mouse is focused on

remarks.para: Each mouse has it's own Control focus. This utility allows interaction with normal widgets as well as SDG Widgets through the standard SDG events.

member.name: E:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseMove
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse event occurs

member.name: E:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseDown
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse button has been pressed

member.name: E:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseUp
member.summary: Event fired when any mouse button has been released

member.name: E:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseWheel
member.summary: Event fired when the mouse wheel has been moved

member.name: T:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseCollection
member.summary: A class which inherits from ReadOnlyCollection Base and represents a collection of mice

remarks.para: To access different mice on the system a collection class was needed. This class will provide array access to the class and will provide a count of the total number of mice on the system.

member.name: M:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseCollection.#ctor(System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: The default constructor for the MouseCollection class requires an array list of mice class

member.name: P:Sdgt.Mouse.MouseCollection.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets the mouse class specified by the index parameter

remarks.para: There are several ways to iterate through all of the mice on the system. One can use a numeric iterator such as "int i" or use a mouse iterator using the foreach parameter.

example.para: C# Eg., for (int i=0; i < sdgManager1.Mice.Count; ++i) { sdgManager1.Mice[i].Text = "Tricks are for kids"; }
C# Eg., foreach (Sdgt.Mouse m in sdgManager1.Mice) { m.Text = "Tricks are for kids"; }

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventHandler
member.summary: The default handler for all sdg mouse events

member.name: T:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs
member.summary: The event class for all sdg mouse events

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This constructor is used for a numeric button assignment corresponding to a Raw Input Command

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This constructor is used for a numeric button assignment corresponding to a Raw Input Command

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Windows.Forms.MouseButtons,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This constructor is used for a MouseButtons enumeration assignment

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.ID
member.summary: Gets the ID of the mouse that raised this mouse event

remarks.para: This is the only property that is additional to the default windows .NET mouse event framework. It represents the ID of the mouse from which this event originated.

example.para: C# Eg., sdgManager1.Mice[e.ID].Text = "X " + e.X + " Y " + e.Y;

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.Button
member.summary: Gets the mouse buttons depressed in this mouse event

remarks.para: Please note that the mouse move event returns all mouse buttons that are current pressed. The mouse down and mouse up events only provide the mouse button which raised that event. This coincides with the .NET mouse event standards. For the mouse move events it is advisable to use the & operator to determine if a particular mouse button has been pressed.

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.X
member.summary: Gets the X position of this mouse event

remarks.para: Please note that the X position provided by this event parameter is always relative to the Control specified in the RelativeTo property. If the ScaleMode property is set to "PixelDelta" then all of the coordinates are relative to the last point provided.

example.para: C# Eg., g.DrawLine(Pens.Black, new Point(e.X,e.Y), new Point(e.X+2,e.Y+2));

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.Y
member.summary: Gets the Y position of this mouse event

remarks.para: Please note that the Y position provided by this event parameter is always relative to the Control specified in the RelativeTo property. If the ScaleMode property is set to "PixelDelta" then all of the coordinates are relative to the last point provided.

example.para: C# Eg., g.DrawLine(Pens.Black, new Point(e.X,e.Y), new Point(e.X+2,e.Y+2));

member.name: P:Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs.Delta
member.summary: Gets the number of detantes the mouse wheel has been moved multiplied by 120

remarks.para: A shift of the scroll wheel is called a detante. Please note that windows by default returns the number of detantes moved multiplied by 120. This means that a Delta value of 120 means that the mouse moveed up one Detante. -240 means the mouse moved down two detantes.

member.name: T:Sdgt.ISdgMouseWidget
member.summary: This is the required interface for all sdg Mouse Widgets, it provides all of the required functionality that any sdg mouse widget would need

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgMouseWidget.OnSdgMouseMove(Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a mouse is moved over this widget

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgMouseWidget.OnSdgMouseDown(Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a mouse button is pressed over this widget

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgMouseWidget.OnSdgMouseUp(Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a mouse button is released after pressing the widget

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgMouseWidget.OnSdgMouseClick(Sdgt.SdgMouseEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a mouse button is released over this widget

member.name: T:Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget
member.summary: This is the required interface for sdg Keyboard Widgets, it provides all of the required functionality that any sdg keyboard enabled widget would need

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget.OnSdgKeyPress(Sdgt.SdgKeyPressEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a keyboard event is pressed and the current widget is focused by that mouse

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget.OnSdgKeyDown(Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a keyboard event is pressed and the current widget is focused by that mouse

member.name: M:Sdgt.ISdgKeyboardWidget.OnSdgKeyUp(Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs)
member.summary: Method fired whenever a keyboard event is released and the current widget is focused by that mouse

member.name: M:Sdgt.SdgControl.OnSdgKeyUp(Sdgt.SdgKeyEventArgs)

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgControl.SdgKeyUp

member.name: E:Sdgt.SdgControl.SdgKeyDown
